title: From cosy fire pits and warm cocktails to ski-in access and private village gondolas: There is so much s'more fun on the slopes

1

The views from the gondola down to the ski resort base in South Lake Tahoe on a blue sky day are just... heavenly.
The glorious piercing blue waters of Lake Tahoe, at 6,250ft, and the snow-clad Sierra Nevada mountains that incorporate the Heavenly ski resort make for a special setting on the borders of California and Nevada in the US.
After the non-stop Virgin Atlantic flight from London and a night in San Francisco’s Fisherman’s Wharf, our first ski on this trip was at Northstar, although the snow was limited.
Guiding star: The glorious views down to Lake Tahoe from Northstar
But the piste-groomers had done a great job at keeping enough terrain open to get the lungs pumping with fresh air and the thighs burning.
They certainly did that after a few laps on the long, single, black-diamond-graded Burnout run, down to the Backside Express chairlift.
This was hard-pack, devoid of sunlight and a challenging pitch, needing concentration, and not just a bit of effort, to keep the ski edges biting.

But Plunge and Westbridge, near Zephyr chair, were relaxing cruising runs, as well as the long, gentle, but rewarding piste down to Northstar village.
It was Northstar that guided me to my first-ever Heavenly ski experience. This is one of Lake Tahoe’s premier ski resorts and being on the north shore of Lake Tahoe, it’s closer to San Francisco (about four hours’ drive) and its international airport.
The resort’s ice-skating rink, with cosy fire pits all around, and choir in full song, is the village centrepiece bringing a lot of warmth to early-season, chilly nights in the Sierra mountains.
I confess that most of the warmth came from the rink-side Cabana bar which serves up a Northstar ‘classic’ cocktail called ‘the dirty snowman’, which mixes hot cocoa, vanilla vodka, Irish cream and hazelnut liqueor.
Need I say more?
If staying, as we did, at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel on the mountain above Northstar village, with its ski-in, ski-out access and own village gondola, then the word ‘more’ is spoken often, and with respect.
More the word ‘s’more’ in fact – the name of the biscuit sandwich, filled with chocolate and marshmallow – yes you’ve guessed it, once you’ve tried one, you have to have s’more!
The Ritz-Carlton has taken the s’more concept to another level by employing its own ‘marshmologist’ to keep up the sticky standards and by offering them free after you return from the slopes.
Away from the Ritz-Carlton, I can also recommend the Lake Tahoe Resort Hotel.
It’s slightly closer to the Heavenly gondola, has spacious rooms (no fireplaces though) and an apres-ski Happy Two Hours when cocktails, beers, wine and pretzels are not cut price, but free! What s’more can I say...
TRAVEL FACTS Virgin Holidays ( virginholidays.co.uk , 0844 557 3859) offers seven nights including one at the Hotel Zephyr in San Francisco’s Fisherman’s Wharf, three at The Ridge At Tahoe and three nights at own arrangement, with return flights from Heathrow to San Francisco and car hire from £849pp.
